Posts.Content: Hi, I contacted my breast nurse at the hospital and she gave me an appointment where she sorted me out one that fits nicely and evens me up.
Posts.Title: Prosthesis after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi, I contacted my breast nurse at the hospital and she gave me an appointment where she sorted me out one that fits nicely and evens me up.
Posts.Title: Prosthesis after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I understand your feelings completely. Someone recommended the book The Cancer Survivor's Handbook by Dr France's Goodhart. I found this really useful as it explained a lot of how people feel when treatment has finished. I bought it on Kindle but I'm sure it's available in other places too.
Posts.Title: Finding the uncertainty unbearable at times

Posts.Content: So, I saw my oncologist just before Christmas. He's a man of few words. I've finished all my treatment - operation, chemotherapy and radiotherapy. He examined me and said all felt okay. He said he'll sort out a mammogram for six months time ...and that was it. So, am I in remission, cured or what? I didn't have chance to ask? He's given me an appointment for a year's time so I assume all is okay!
Posts.Title: Remission????

Posts.Content: Thank you.
Posts.Title: Remission????

Posts.Content: I had a lumpectomy in February and feel exactly the same. Some days are better than others but sometimes I can feel upset by the smallest thing. I think emotions are just raw at the moment. My hardest thing to deal with is people saying I look well after the operation and it's good to see I'm recovering when I feel drained still and know I have 18 weeks of chemotherapy ahead. I hope it helps to know someone else feels the same.
Posts.Title: Every day stress

Posts.Content: Thank you ohmyG.
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm having the first lot of chemo this Friday (6 in total) and wondered what advice anyone has.
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Thank you Dreamthief. Appointment is at 10am so from the sounds if it, that should be okay.
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Explain how you are feeling at the appointment but if you're worried contact your breast nurse who can see you sooner.  I contacted mine six months after treatment as my breast had shrunk and she reassured me it was due to the radiotherapy and was quite normal.  Don't worry that it's been some time since your treatment, they are still there to look after you.
Posts.Title: Tender still after a year .

Posts.Content: Where to start? I’m  5 years post breast cancer for which I had a lumpectomy, chemotherapy and radiotherapy and I’ve just found out that I have a tumour on one of my ribs - metastasised from my breast cancer. My head is in a whirl. I can’t think straight. Now waiting for an appointment to see an oncologist. Any advice welcome.
Posts.Title: Cancer’s back

Posts.Content: Thank you for your kind words. I had a chest X-ray asi had a persistent cough - lungs fine but they found the tumour on my rib. Yes, it’s the not knowing what’s ahead that is difficult.
Posts.Title: Cancer’s back

Posts.Content: Thank you. It sounds like you’ve been through a lot.
Posts.Title: Cancer’s back

Posts.Content: Hi Minnie ha ha, I too was terrified but have now finished 6 lots of FEC. During the first session, I was allowed to have my daughter stay with me. The nurses were great and talked me through the whole process. You get to know the nurses through the process so be honest with them and they'll help you with any worries. Give yourself a treat for each session and try to focus on the fact that each one is one less to have - it helped me.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo and terrified!

Posts.Content: Thank you.
Posts.Title: Cancer’s back

Posts.Content: I had a lumpectomy on 13th February for a grade 3 ductal invasive carcinoma and am due to start having chemotherapy soon. I would love to meet someone who is going through the same journey as me who lives locally, just to meet for a coffee and have some mutual support.
Posts.Title: Meet people in Sleaford, Lincolnshire

Posts.Content: Hi Hiloa, the nearest support I can find is about 15 miles away so I was looking for someone more local. Hi Rebecca, I am looking forward to meeting up.
Posts.Title: Meet people in Sleaford, Lincolnshire

Posts.Content: For anyone worried about meeting someone from the internet, I'd say go for it. From this experience, I was lucky to meet Rebecca who is an inspiration. She could tell me lots of advice and tips about her journey and inspired me to see that people can get through this. Thank you, Rebecca.
Posts.Title: Meet people in Sleaford, Lincolnshire

Posts.Content: No, you didn't talk to much. It was great to meet someone who has come through all his. I'll be touch once I'm passed the first hurdle. x
Posts.Title: Meet people in Sleaford, Lincolnshire

Posts.Content: A soft bra is essential - find one that doesn't have any wire.  Some sports bras are ideal while you are waiting for your appointment.  Hope you get sorted soon.
Posts.Title: New to group and feeling bit lost

Posts.Content: Hi Penny, I had a WLE in February having been diagnosed with a grade 3 invasive ductal carcinoma. I ended up staying in hospital overnight as my operation was longer than expected. I definitely needed support for the first few days especially as I went home with a drain in. As to going back to work, I didn't because I felt I couldn't cope with the responsibility and long days but I suppose it depends what you do. My doctor has signed me off for three months initially as I'm now on the chemo roller coaster and actually now expect to be off work for six months before I've finished all my treatment - again I suppose it depends what you do but I know I couldn't do my job and cope with this treatment. If you don't have anyone who can stay with you, you need to talk to your breast nurse or GP to look at giving you support at key times. Please don't try to cope with this alone.
Posts.Title: scared and angry

Posts.Content: Has anyone else had to cope with their fingernails turning black? I've noticed that my nails are looking black above the half moons, almost like having an extra half moon but a black one - if that makes sense. I've just had my 4th lot of FEC and wonder if this will continue to get worse. I've got two more cycles to go. Is it okay to paint my nails to hide the black?
Posts.Title: Fingernails turning black

Posts.Content: Thank you Dreamthief x
Posts.Title: Fingernails turning black

Posts.Content: Hi Andrea, it's a massive shock to find out you have cancer. I found out back in January, had an op, and have just finished 6 lots of chemo. Just radiotherapy to go now. My main advice to you is to take each stage at a time, trying to look too far ahead is too mammoth a task to consider. Take someone with you to take notes at appointments as there is always too much to take in. Accept help - you can't do this alone. I'm sorry you've joined this roller coaster. At the time it feels like it is going on for ever but there is light at the end of the tunnel, take care.
Posts.Title: New Person!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Andrea, it's a massive shock to find out you have cancer. I found out back in January, had an op, and have just finished 6 lots of chemo. Just radiotherapy to go now. My main advice to you is to take each stage at a time, trying to look too far ahead is too mammoth a task to consider. Take someone with you to take notes at appointments as there is always too much to take in. Accept help - you can't do this alone. I'm sorry you've joined this roller coaster. At the time it feels like it is going on for ever but there is light at the end of the tunnel, take care.
Posts.Title: New Person!!!

Posts.Content: I've spent a lovely afternoon at one of the Look Good, Feel Better events and I have to say if you feel like being pampered then book yourself onto a session. These are free and run at several hospitals around the country. Cosmetic manufacturers donate their products and you are taught how to look good whilst having cancer. You come out looking glamorous and with a huge goody bag of make up too. Can't recommend it enough. You can find more information at www.lgfb.co.uk
Posts.Title: Look Good, Feel Better
